Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling is preparing for a stressful final exam and is feeling anxious about the outcome.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: The regular backup is away, so most congregants expect him to step forward for the scheduled prayer.
Story: I sat on the edge of my bed, my phone buzzing with messages from the mosque committee, reminding me that the backup imam was out of town and everyone was counting on me to lead the evening prayer. At the same time, I could hear my stepbrother pacing in the next room, his anxiety almost palpable as he muttered formulas under his breath, preparing for his final exam tomorrow. I knew he needed me—he always said I was the only one who could calm him down before big tests. But the thought of letting down the congregation, who trusted me to guide them in prayer, weighed heavily on my heart. My mind raced with the expectations: to be a source of comfort for my brother, to be a pillar of faith for my community. I felt torn, guilt gnawing at me no matter which way I turned. The call to prayer echoed from my phone, and my brother’s voice cracked as he called out for me. My hands trembled, caught between two worlds, each demanding a part of me I wasn’t sure I could give.
